project_metadata.paper_title: Barbarophonos: Language and Panhellenism in the Iliad
project_metadata.research_context: This paper examines linguistic patterns in Homer's Iliad to assess the extent of Panhellenic identity in eighth-century BCE Greece. Through analysis of passages addressing language differences among Trojans and their allies versus the linguistic unity of the Achaeans, the author argues for an early, non-oppositional form of proto-Panhellenism.

evidence.evidence_text: Linguistic diversity is acknowledged in Iliad 2.802-6 when Iris warns Hektor about the many languages spoken among the Trojan allies
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three passages in the Iliad directly address the speaking of different languages (Il. 2.802–6, 2.867, 4.433–38; Od. 19.172–77, each discussed below).

evidence.evidence_text: The phrase 'ἄλλη δ᾽ ἄλλων γλῶσσα πολυσπερέων ἀνθρώπων' explicitly states different tongues among the wide-strewn human race, requiring interpreters for communication
evidence.verbatim_quote: The phrase ἄλλη δ᾽ ἄλλων γλῶσσα πολυσπερέων ἀνθρώπων ('but there are different tongues among the wide-strewn human race') makes it clear that the ἐπίκουροι speak various mutually unintelligible languages; otherwise, there would be no need to dispatch each leader to command his own troops.

evidence.evidence_text: The Karians are labelled βαρβαρόφωνος in Iliad 2.867-69, the only use of a barbaros cognate in the Iliad and in Greek literature prior to the latter half of the sixth century BCE
evidence.verbatim_quote: This passage marks the only use of a βάρβαρος cognate or compound in the Iliad. Indeed, this is the only use of a βάρβαρος-cognate in Greek literature prior to the latter half of the sixth century B.C.E. (Anac. frag. 423 Page; see J. Hall 2002, 111–12).

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items concern the barbarophonos adjective and its significance. The chronological scope is now included in the combined observation.

evidence.evidence_text: In Iliad 4.433-38, three words for language (θρόος, γῆρυς, γλῶσσα) emphasise the cacophony of the Trojan host
evidence.verbatim_quote: Three words, θρόος, γῆρυς, and γλῶσσα, used for language in two separate clauses, invoke the discord of the scene, emphasizing the fact that the languages spoken among the ἐπίκουροι are diverse, numerous, and—when considered in the context of Iliad 2.802–6, where interpreters prove necessary—mutually unintelligible.

evidence.evidence_text: The linguistic diversity passage uses the phrase 'γλῶσσα μέμικτο' (their tongue was mingled) because they were 'πολύκλητοι' (summoned from many lands)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, just as language is subordinate to πόλις and military divisions in Iliad 2.802–6, linguistic variation here depends upon place of origin: γλῶσσα μέμικτο ('their tongue was mingled') because they were πολύκλητοι ('summoned from many lands').

evidence.evidence_text: Odyssey 19.172-77 is the only recognition of linguistic diversity within Akhaian lands in early literature, listing five ethno-linguistic groups on Krete without distinguishing Greek from non-Greek
evidence.verbatim_quote: The only recognition of linguistic diversity within Akhaian lands found in early literature occurs in the Odyssey. Groups traditionally considered Greek (Akhaians and Dorians) are not, however, distinguished from those who were not (Eteocretans, Kudones, Pelasgians); again, no rigid dichotomy emerges between Akhaians and non-Akhaians.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items address the same Odyssey passage on Krete and its implications for ethno-linguistic categories.

evidence.evidence_text: Hesiod's Theogony 824-35 describes Typhoeus as producing divine speech and animal sounds but no human language, exploring divine-human contrast rather than human diversity
evidence.verbatim_quote: The passage from Hesiod deals not with diversity of human language, but instead focuses on differences between divine, human, and animal utterances.

evidence.evidence_text: The Homeric Hymn to Delian Apollo 156-64 describes the Delian maidens mimicking the speech of all peoples, presupposing human linguistic diversity
evidence.verbatim_quote: Here, each listener, no matter which of the φῦλ᾽ ἀνθρώπων ('tribes of people') he comes from, hears the Delian maidens singing in his own language.

evidence.evidence_text: In the Hymn to Aphrodite 111-16, Aphrodite explains she can speak Ankhises' language because she was raised by a Trojan nurse, with emphatic adverbs and particles strengthening the explanation
evidence.verbatim_quote: Just as interpreters were employed in the Iliad to facilitate communication between Trojans and ἐπίκουροι, here Aphrodite concocts an identity as a Phrygian princess who can only speak with Ankhises because she was brought up by a Trojan nurse, who taught her Ankhises' language. Not only is a four-line explanatory tale provided, but it is quite vigorous, bracketed by numerous emphatic adverbs, particles, and conjunctions in lines 113 and 116 (σάφα… δή τοι . . . γε καί); redundancy between lines 113 and 116 further strengthens the emphasis.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items address the Hymn to Aphrodite passage and its emphatic explanation of linguistic competence.

evidence.evidence_text: The Karians appear next-to-last in the geographically-arranged Trojan Catalogue, and language is mentioned only once in the Catalogues, marked by a single adjective
evidence.verbatim_quote: The idea of remoteness is reinforced by the fact that the Karians occur next-to-last in the Trojan Catalogue, which appears to be arranged in geographical order. Notably, language is only mentioned once in the Catalogues of Iliad 2, in which Homer delineates and describes the opposing forces. Even here it is of relatively minor importance, marked by a single adjective, before the poet returns to more commonly invoked and salient criteria of identity.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items concern the Catalogue structure and what it reveals about the role of language in identity.

evidence.evidence_text: Homer consistently uses singular γαῖα to describe the Akhaian homeland and λαός for the Akhaians as a whole
evidence.verbatim_quote: Another indication of a complex unity among the Akhaians is that Homer consistently uses the singular γαῖα (or αἶα or πατρὶς γαῖα) to describe the place from which the Akhaian force was mustered and to which its members want to return. Similarly, the term λαός (people) is used in the singular when referring to the Akhaians as a whole.

evidence.evidence_text: Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely without language barriers in face-to-face encounters throughout the Iliad
evidence.verbatim_quote: Furthermore, never in the Iliad is there a language barrier between Akhaian and Trojan; heroes from both camps freely communicate in face-to-face encounters.

evidence.evidence_text: The Iliad 1.403-4 provides two names for Briareos/Aigaion - one divine, one human - exemplifying the human-divine linguistic distinction
evidence.verbatim_quote: Providing two names—one divine, the other human—both exemplifies the concern of Greek epic with the division between the human and the divine and offers the poet an opportunity to display his privileged knowledge of the names used by the gods.

evidence.evidence_text: The sheep simile comparing Trojans to bleating ewes in Iliad 4 is not limited to Trojans - Akhaians are also compared to animal groups in Iliad 2
evidence.verbatim_quote: The sheep simile is not limited to the Trojans or intrinsically derogatory; in Il. 2, the Akhaians are also compared to groups of animals. The poet develops no dichotomy between Akhaians and non-Akhaians along the lines of speaking versus bleating, human versus animal.

evidence.evidence_text: Herodotus 8.144 identifies language as one of three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and common religion
evidence.verbatim_quote: Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion.

evidence.evidence_text: The Phrygians are described as remote in the Trojan Catalogue with the phrase 'τηλ᾽ ἐξ' (from afar), and Otreus is named by Priam as a contemporary of his youth
evidence.verbatim_quote: As is typical in the Iliad, in the Hymn to Aphrodite γλῶσσα is associated with place of origin, in this case Phrygia. Furthermore, although no mention of Phrygian linguistic difference appears in the Iliad itself, the remoteness of the Phrygian homeland is noted by the phrase τῆλ' ἐξ, 'from afar,' in the Trojan Catalogue (2.862–63). Elsewhere in the Iliad (3.181–90), the Otreus mentioned in the Hymn to Aphrodite is named by Priam as a contemporary of his youth.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items concern Phrygian remoteness and connections to the Hymn to Aphrodite.

claims.claim_text: The instances of linguistic diversity in the Iliad follow a consistent pattern that recognises diversity among Trojan allies while suppressing it among Akhaians
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the speaking of different languages is only rarely acknowledged in early epic poetry, the Iliad included, the instances of linguistic diversity that do occur in the Iliad follow a consistent pattern.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan ἐπίκουροι while absent from the Akhaian forces
claims.verbatim_quote: On the other hand, through poetic emphasis or suppression, linguistic diversity is limited to the Trojan ἐπίκουροι (allies or companions) defending the city, while it is absent from the Akhaian forces besieging Troy.

claims.claim_text: The Trojan allies' languages are characterised as diverse, numerous, and mutually unintelligible, requiring interpreters
claims.verbatim_quote: Three words, θρόος, γῆρυς, and γλῶσσα, used for language in two separate clauses, invoke the discord of the scene, emphasizing the fact that the languages spoken among the ἐπίκουροι are diverse, numerous, and—when considered in the context of Iliad 2.802–6, where interpreters prove necessary—mutually unintelligible.

claims.claim_text: The adjective βαρβαρόφωνος in Homer likely denotes strange speech generally rather than specifically non-Greek speech
claims.verbatim_quote: It is likely that the adjective βαρβαρόφωνος here does not denote merely non-Greek (or, more properly, non-Akhaian) speech, but instead carries the force of strange speech more generally, since every other passage in the Iliad that concerns the use of mutually incomprehensible languages refers not to a divide between Akhaians and non-Akhaian divisions, but instead to differences between ἐπίκουροι and Trojans (or among ἐπίκουροι).

claims.claim_text: The Karians are set apart as strange and foreign in general, remote from Akhaians, Trojans, and perhaps other ἐπίκουροι
claims.verbatim_quote: In other words, the poet is not only, or even primarily, drawing a distinction between the Karians and the Akhaians (or between the Karians and his Greek-speaking audience), but instead is setting the Karians apart as strange and foreign in general, far removed not just from the Akhaians but also from the Trojans themselves and perhaps even from the other ἐπίκουροι.

claims.claim_text: The contrast between Akhaian linguistic unity and Trojan cacophony represents a contrast between Akhaian order and Trojan disorder
claims.verbatim_quote: In this context, the Akhaian unity of language, versus the Trojan-allied disunity, is a contrast between Trojan clamor and chaos on the one hand and Akhaian cohesion and order on the other.

claims.claim_text: Language is not the most important criterion of identity in the Iliad; it is coupled with or subordinate to place of origin or military contingent membership
claims.verbatim_quote: First, language is not the most important criterion of identity; in all three passages it is coupled with, or even subordinate to, place of origin or membership in a particular military retinue.

claims.claim_text: Krete is depicted as linguistically diverse and exotic, perhaps to emphasise its strangeness despite being ruled by an Akhaian king
claims.verbatim_quote: In this case, ethno-linguistic diversity would make Krete strange and distant, perhaps even 'foreign,' despite the fact that the island is ruled by an Akhaian king and sent a contingent to the Trojan War.

claims.claim_text: No rigid dichotomy emerges between Akhaians and non-Akhaians in the Odyssey passage on Krete - the Odyssey 19.175-77 may be the sole Homeric example combining descent-based ethnicity with linguistically-expressed group identity
claims.verbatim_quote: Groups traditionally considered Greek (Akhaians and Dorians) are not, however, distinguished from those who were not (Eteocretans, Kudones, Pelasgians); again, no rigid dichotomy emerges between Akhaians and non-Akhaians. Odyssey 19.175–77 is perhaps the sole example in Homer where J. Hall's idea of ethnicity—communal identity conferred at birth by putative descent—is combined with language to produce the genealogically-determined, but linguistically-expressed, groups that J. Hall claims are the most salient category of identity in Archaic Greece.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims address the same Odyssey passage and its implications for identity categories.

claims.claim_text: The contrast between human and divine speech is a recurrent theme in the epic tradition, with Hesiod and Homer exploring this division through different naming practices
claims.verbatim_quote: Unlike Homer, Hesiod never recognizes differences between human languages. Instead, his only mention of language involves divine speech, contrasted with the inarticulate sounds made by animals. The contrast between the human and the divine, a recurrent theme in the epic tradition, manifests itself through the allocation of different names to the same creature or place by men on the one hand and gods on the other.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims concern the human-divine language contrast theme.

claims.claim_text: The scene of the Delian maidens presupposes human linguistic diversity as what makes their performance remarkable
claims.verbatim_quote: Whether the utterance of words comprehensible to all listeners is the product of the singers' skill—implied by the phrases μιμεῖσθ' ἴσασιν and οὕτω σφιν καλὴ συνάρηρεν ἀοιδή—or the result of some divine miracle—evoked by such words as θαῦμα and θέλγουσι—for the scene to be considered remarkable requires the imagined audience to come to the performance of the maidens speaking a multitude of languages.

claims.claim_text: Divine or divinely-inspired speech transcends individual human languages in the early epic tradition
claims.verbatim_quote: If the simultaneous understanding of the φῦλ᾽ ἀνθρώπων is the result of a miracle, it implies that divine or divinely inspired speech transcends individual human languages, again pointing to a contrast between human speech and the speech of the gods.

claims.claim_text: The Hymn to Aphrodite mirrors the Iliad's pattern of linguistic division between Trojans and ἐπίκουροι
claims.verbatim_quote: Moreover, the case of Aphrodite involves communication between a Phrygian—Phrygians being future ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans—and Ankhises, a Trojan nobleman, echoing the theme from the Iliad that the ἐπίκουροι speak a variety of languages distinct from each other and differing from Trojan speech.

claims.claim_text: The image of linguistic diversity among the Trojan ἐπίκουροι had solidified within the epic tradition by the time of the Hymn to Aphrodite
claims.verbatim_quote: In this context, the poet's need to provide a Phrygian princess with a Trojan education in order to explain how she can converse with Ankhises illustrates the degree to which the image of linguistic diversity among the ἐπίκουροι of the Trojans found in the Iliad had solidified within the epic tradition.

claims.claim_text: Language functions as a marker of alterity in the early epic tradition, indicating strangeness, difference, and distance
claims.verbatim_quote: In the Odyssey and in the Theogony, and sometimes in the Iliad, the speaking of a strange language indicates just that, strangeness, difference, and distance. Language as a marker of alterity joins Odysseus' tale of an exotic Krete with Hesiod's image of the horrific beast Typhoeus—and both with the description of the remote Karians in the Trojan Catalogue.

claims.claim_text: Homer's consistent use of singular terms for Akhaian homeland and people indicates complex unity among the Akhaians
claims.verbatim_quote: Another indication of a complex unity among the Akhaians is that Homer consistently uses the singular γαῖα (or αἶα or πατρὶς γαῖα) to describe the place from which the Akhaian force was mustered and to which its members want to return.

claims.claim_text: No hard linguistic dividing line between Akhaians and others emerges in the Iliad, and the later categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy had not yet emerged
claims.verbatim_quote: On the one hand, Akhaians and Trojans communicate freely with one another; no hard linguistic dividing line between Akhaians and others emerges over the course of the epic, nor does it appear that the later, categorical Greek-Barbarian dichotomy has yet emerged.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims express the same core idea about absence of Greek-Barbarian dichotomy.

claims.claim_text: The term 'barbarian' had not yet acquired its later pejorative connotation in the Iliad
claims.verbatim_quote: Cartledge (1993, 13) observes that 'Not once is 'barbarian' used as either a substantive or adjective in all . . . of Homer.' Elsewhere, Cartledge adds that the single appearance of βαρβαρόφωνος lacks any negative overtones (Cartledge 1995, 78).

claims.claim_text: The poet develops no dichotomy between Akhaians and non-Akhaians along the lines of speaking versus bleating or human versus animal
claims.verbatim_quote: The poet develops no dichotomy between Akhaians and non-Akhaians along the lines of speaking versus bleating, human versus animal. Instead, emphasis is on uniformity versus diversity, Akhaian order versus non-Akhaian chaos.

claims.claim_text: In Classical Era Panhellenism, speaking a single tongue was central to Hellenic identity
claims.verbatim_quote: In the Classical Era, language was central to Panhellenism. Herodotus considers speaking a single tongue to be one of the three central elements of Hellenic identity, along with shared customs and a common religion.

claims.claim_text: Aphrodite's defensive explanation of her linguistic competence suggests that meeting a stranger who speaks one's language perfectly might indicate divine identity
claims.verbatim_quote: Perhaps meeting a stranger who can speak his language perfectly strikes Ankhises as odd, something that might be explained were his interlocutor divine, which he already suspects from her beauty and bearing. Combating his suspicion, Aphrodite takes some care to concoct a plausible and forceful explanation.

claims.claim_text: The differential treatment of linguistic diversity reveals a nascent, non-oppositional proto-Panhellenism based on Akhaian homogeneity
claims.verbatim_quote: This differential treatment of Akhaian and Trojan forces reveals a notion of 'pan-Akhaian' linguistic uniformity, distinct from the cacophony of the Trojan host, perhaps indicating the coalescing of a non-oppositional but shared Greek identity.

claims.claim_text: The linguistic unity of the Akhaians is one sign of their success at community building, contrasting with Trojan failure
claims.verbatim_quote: Taken in this light, the linguistic unity of the Akhaians is one sign of their success at community building; the babble and clamor of the Trojans a mark of their failure.

claims.claim_text: The Iliad captures Panhellenism at the stage of an operationally unified 'us' versus a diverse, plural 'those others'
claims.verbatim_quote: Instead, the development of Panhellenism has been captured at the stage of an operationally but incompletely unified 'us' versus a diverse, plural 'those others.'

claims.claim_text: The poems substantially preserve versions current during the late eighth century BCE, with the Iliad perhaps somewhat earlier than the Odyssey
claims.verbatim_quote: I believe, however, that the poems as we have them substantially preserve versions current during the late eighth century, with the Iliad perhaps somewhat earlier than the Odyssey. I have settled on these dates not only because the epics appear, linguistically, to be earlier than other Greek poetry, but especially for the reason Gregory Nagy proposed: that by about 700 B.C.E. the poems were so widely diffused that opportunities for recomposition would have been limited by the expectations of a large, diverse, and informed audience.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both claims form a single methodological argument about poem dating.

claims.claim_text: Linguistic arrangements in the Iliad reflect beliefs about language and identity contemporary with the moment of stabilisation around the turn of the eighth century
claims.verbatim_quote: Thus, linguistic arrangements in the Iliad likely reflect the present of poet and audience around the time of stabilization, shaped by contemporary conditions, needs, and ideas.

claims.claim_text: Physical things are more durable in oral tradition than abstractions about institutions and relationships
claims.verbatim_quote: Physical things, be they objects or places, are much more durable in oral tradition—hence the appearance of boars' tusk helmets and the preeminence of Mycenae in the Iliad. By contrast, so long as it is evolving through recomposition, oral tradition only tends to retain information about institutions and relationships so long as they are immediately relevant to the poet's audience or relate directly to contemporary social structures.

claims.claim_text: Assigning a direct equation of Akhaians with Greeks and Trojans with barbarians to an eighth-century performance is anachronistic
claims.verbatim_quote: Even though later Greeks—after the Persian Wars, perhaps—may have directly equated Akhaians with Greeks and Trojans with barbarians as they heard or read the Iliad, assigning such an understanding of identity to an eighth-century B.C.E. performance is anachronistic, unsupported by the linguistic situation depicted in the epics.

claims.claim_text: Human linguistic variation accounts for more instances of linguistic diversity in early epic than the human-divine dichotomy
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, human linguistic variation accounts for more of the instances of linguistic diversity noted in the early epic tradition than does the human-divine dichotomy, even among examples taken from outside the Iliad.

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The author identifies consistency in linguistic treatment across multiple passages but assumes this consistency reflects deliberate tradition rather than coincidence or compositional constraint. This assumption enables treating the pattern as evidence of beliefs rather than mere convention.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: What the poet suppresses or fails to mention is as significant as what is explicitly stated for understanding cultural attitudes

The near-total absence of language from the Catalogues
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument depends on interpreting absence of mention as meaningful rather than accidental. The author treats the failure to mention linguistic diversity among Akhaians as evidence of a cultural assumption of homogeneity, rather than as simply irrelevant to the narrative.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Ancient audiences would have recognised and interpreted linguistic patterns similarly to modern scholarly analysis

the audience found the linguistically homogenous Akhaians familiar
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The argument moves from textual observation to claims about audience reception without explicit evidence of ancient audience responses. The assumption that literary devices require cultural resonance bridges the gap between text and social function.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The contrast between Akhaian order and Trojan disorder in the epic reflects actual eighth-century Greek perceptions of identity difference

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Scholars who emphasise oppositional identity formation and those who emphasise aggregative identity formation are addressing the same phenomenon differently rather than describing different phenomena

Those who view Panhellenism as aggregated from disparate local and regional identities allow for its earlier appearance

This enables positioning the Iliad evidence as contributing to the debate rather than requiring its own theoretical framework.

research_designs.design_description: Interpretive framework based on two explicit premises: (1) the Iliad stabilised circa 700 BCE due to wide dispersion limiting recomposition, and (2) oral tradition reflects beliefs contemporary with stabilisation rather than the mythological past
research_designs.verbatim_quote: In short, the Iliad is the product of an oral tradition that stabilized in approximately its current form circa 700 B.C.E. Due to the nature of oral tradition, the poem for the most part reflects beliefs about language and identity roughly contemporary with the moment of stabilization. Based upon these two premises, I will attempt to interpret the linguistic situation in the Iliad as it would have been understood by poet and audience at about the time of stabilization, around the turn of the eighth century.
research_designs.rationale: The author explicitly states these two premises as the foundation for interpreting linguistic patterns in the Iliad as evidence of eighth-century proto-Panhellenism

research_designs.design_description: Comparative analysis of linguistic patterns across the early Greek epic corpus to contextualise Iliad passages
research_designs.verbatim_quote: The nature and importance of these passages can be better assessed by interpreting them in the context of the surviving body of early Greek epic poetry. The speaking of divergent languages is acknowledged once in the Odyssey, once in Hesiod's Theogony, and twice in the Homeric Hymns.
research_designs.rationale: The author explicitly justifies expanding the evidence base beyond the Iliad to include other early epic texts for comparative analysis
expected_information_missing: No systematic corpus selection criteria stated
No justification for excluding other archaic texts

methods.method_description: Comparative textual analysis across early epic corpus (Iliad, Odyssey, Hesiod, Homeric Hymns) to identify patterns in linguistic representation
methods.verbatim_quote: Admittedly, only three passages from the Iliad deal with Akhaian linguistic unity or the linguistic diversity of the Trojan ejpÇkouroi, making it difficult to determine the significance of language as a component of early Panhellenism. The nature and importance of these passages can be better assessed by interpreting them in the context of the surviving body of early Greek epic poetry.
